channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Zelensky Says Traitors Could Undermine Ukraine War Effort
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said hundreds of employees of the nation’s law enforcement agencies are suspected of working with Russia. U.S. officials said that Russia may turn to Iran to replenish its depleted fleet of drones.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: U.K. Heat Live Updates: Wales Appears to Set Record High, as Britain Sizzles
item.description: A country largely without air conditioning was struggling to cope in the heat. Rail service was limited for fear the tracks would buckle, and a London bridge was partly wrapped in reflective foil.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Sunrise in Cornwall, England, on Monday. Britain has declared a national emergency in the face of potentially life-threatening heat.

item.title: Flood, Evacuate, Rinse, Repeat: A Relentless Pattern Batters Australia
item.description: Storms brought 30 inches of rain to areas near Sydney recently, and some residents have seen their homes flooded for the third or fourth time in 16 months.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Isabella Moore for The New York Times
item.media:description: Water covered the streets recently in Windsor, Australia, which sits on a floodplain.

item.title: Plans to Fight Global Warming Face an Obstacle in Paris: Trees
item.description: As a new heat wave bakes the French capital and the rest of Europe, critics say that plans to make the city greener have led to the felling of trees essential to combating rising temperatures.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The lawns surrounding the Eiffel Tower have become the scene of furious protests over plans to cut down trees in the area as part of an effort to build a huge garden.

item.title: Reunited in Bucha, a Ukrainian Family Comes to Terms With War’s Traumas
item.description: As flowers bloom amid the wreckage, the Kyiv suburb synonymous with atrocity feels almost normal again. But the lives of the people there may never be.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yehor Stanislavchuk showing family members where a Russian tank column was destroyed in Bucha.

item.title: Japan’s Leader Tries to Honor Abe’s Legacy, While Building His Own
item.description: Prime Minister Fumio Kishida says he will pursue Shinzo Abe’s goals, such as a stronger military. But he has also set himself apart from his slain predecessor.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.media:description: Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, center, and other officials outside his Tokyo office on Tuesday, as the hearse carrying Shinzo Abe’s body briefly stopped there.

item.title: Mexico’s Leader Says Poverty Is His Priority. But His Policies Hurt the Poor.
item.description: Halfway into the president’s term, the plight of Mexico’s lower classes has only worsened. Economists say it is the result of government mismanagement of welfare programs and the economy.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Oscar Lopez
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students in a classroom at the Adolfo López Mateos Elementary School, run out of an abandoned train carriage in Naucalpan, Mexico.

item.title: Britain Girds for Scorching Heat That Could Break Records
item.description: Temperatures may top 100 degrees Fahrenheit in some areas, a rarity that has prompted a national emergency.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: People sat on the sun-parched grass in Greenwich Park in London on Sunday.

item.title: Extreme Heat Continues Its March Across Western Europe
item.description: A heat wave that has caused fires to rage in southwestern France and Spain is moving north toward Britain, which may see its highest recorded temperatures ever.
item.dc:creator: Kaly Soto
item.media:description: At the beach in Brighton, an oasis in southern England.

item.title: Ukrainian Cargo Plane Bound for Bangladesh Crashes in Greece
item.description: Eight Ukrainian citizens were killed when the cargo plane transporting 11.5 tons of weapons crashed in a field in Greece.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: A view of the crash site of an Antonov An-12 cargo plane owned by a Ukrainian company, near Kavala, Greece, on Sunday.

item.title: Prime Minister Race in Britain Remains Unsettled in Wake of Johnson’s Downfall
item.description: Rishi Sunak, the former chancellor of the Exchequer, is the current front-runner, but Penny Mordaunt, a junior trade minister, is making a surprisingly strong run for the leadership position.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Penny Mordaunt, a junior trade minister, has seen her profile rise swiftly in the campaign for prime minister.

item.title: Putin Aims to Shape a New Generation of Supporters, Through Schools
item.description: Sweeping changes in the curriculum will soon cast the Russian president as a pivotal historical figure and mark an end of openness to the West.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: School-aged children last year at an award ceremony in Vladimir, Russia.

item.title: Italy’s Crisis Redoubles European Foreboding
item.description: Europe is being tested, not only in its united front to Russia, but in the very resilience of its democracies, as nationalist forces sympathetic to Russia remain untamed.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: The potential departure of Prime Minister Mario Draghi of Italy, a symbol of European resolve and stability, has unnerved the continent.

item.title: Londoners React to the U.K. Heat Wave
item.description: The high temperatures in the British capital brought a range of reactions, from anxiety to indifference.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Christine Hauser
item.media:description: A parched St. James’s Park in London, where temperatures were approaching a record on Monday and it was expected to be even hotter the next day.

item.title: The Unraveling of an Award-Winning Documentary
item.description: The director of “Sabaya,” about Yazidi women who had been sexually enslaved by ISIS, says that he wasn’t present for a key scene and that he substituted footage.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Contenders to Replace Boris Johnson Don’t Dwell on Global Warming
item.description: The contenders to replace Mr. Johnson as Britain’s prime minister focused more on rising energy bills than on global warming during a debate on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The five contenders to succeed Boris Johnson as Britain’s next prime minister met for a debate in London on Sunday.

item.title: Why Don’t Homes in Britain Have Air Conditioning?
item.description: It’s usually not hot enough to need it, and homes were built to retain heat, not stay cool.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Attempting to keep out the sun and heat at a home near Reading in Britain on Monday.

item.title: Firefighters in France Battle Wildfires Amid Sweltering Heat
item.description: Local authorities were bracing for the worst on Monday, as a heat wave is expected to hit with full force.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Firefighters working to control a forest fire in Louchats, in southwestern France, on Sunday.

item.title: How to Stay Cool Without Air Conditioning
item.description: One in five homes are likely to overheat, U.K. government officials said. Using window shades and turning off unnecessary lights could help beat the heat.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Yui Mok/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Using a fan indoors can be useful during extreme heat, but officials warn not to aim them directly at the body.

item.title: England’s Transportation Network Strains Under the Heat
item.description: Just 40 percent of London’s Tube network has air conditioning.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Commuters at Victoria Station in London were greeted with message boards warning travelers of disruptions due to extreme heat on Monday.

item.title: A Wilting Climate Response
item.description: As another heat wave descends, the U.S. federal government is pulling back from the climate fight. What now?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Heat in Nice, France, yesterday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A heat wave in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Beachgoers in Brighton, southern England, on Sunday. Temperatures in London are forecast to hit 100 or higher on Monday and Tuesday.

item.title: Global Central Banks Ramp Up Inflation Fight
item.description: Central banks in the U.S., Europe, Canada and parts of Asia are lifting interest rates rapidly as they try to wrestle breakneck inflation under control.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek and Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Hannah Reyes Morales for The New York Times
item.media:description: The central bank in the Philippines surprised investors with a three-quarter point move last week.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: In Mideast, Biden Eyes China and Russia
item.description: Also, a heat wave is sweeping across Europe and Egypt is jailing political prisoners.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: President Biden and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, right, during the GCC + 3 Summit meeting, in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, on Saturday.

item.title: Zelensky Fires His Prosecutor General and Intelligence Chief
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Iryna Venediktova, the prosecutor general of Ukraine, in March.

item.title: Family Members Mourn a 4-Year-Old Girl Killed in Russian Missile Attack
item.description: The death of Liza Dmytriyeva, a 4-year-old with Down syndrome, encapsulated the brutality of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Family members and loved ones at the funeral of Liza Dmytriyeva in Vinnytsia, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: On Ukraine Front Line in Donetsk, Small Victories Carry a Heavy Toll
item.description: Ukrainian soldiers say they live under almost constant Russian bombardment but dismiss any suggestion that they cede land.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers taking a break in the minutes after Russian rockets struck a residential area of Bakhmut, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: A Young Woman’s Ukraine War Task: Encouraging Evacuations
item.description: In phone calls, doorstep conversations and public speeches, Yana Muravinets has tried to convince people that it’s time to leave villages around the embattled southern city of Mykolaiv.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola

item.title: Peeling Paint in Hong Kong Reveals Work of Newly Relevant ‘King’
item.description: When he was alive, the graffiti of Tsang Tsou-choi, or the “King of Kowloon,” was considered peculiar and personal. In a radically changed city, his mostly vanished art now has a political charge.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times
item.media:description: When work by the graffiti artist Tsang Tsou-choi re-emerged beneath a Hong Kong bridge, the mundane setting became an unlikely attraction in a city where dissent has been stamped out.

item.title: Why Union Drives Are Succeeding
item.description: College-educated workers are driving a spike in union organizing.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Brendan Bannon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jaz Brisack, a Rhodes scholar, on her way to work in February at a Starbucks in Buffalo, where she helped unionize co-workers.

item.title: Lily Safra, Star-Crossed Socialite and Philanthropist, Dies at 87
item.description: Her life was marked by tragedy, including the bizarre death of her fourth husband, but that did not stop her from giving away millions.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Lily Safra in 1991. She led what might have seemed to be a charmed life, but the glamour was offset by heartbreak.

item.title: More accounts of abuses in so-called Russian filtration camps in new report add to international concern.
item.dc:creator: Maham Javaid
item.media:description: Buses carrying evacuated civilians in the village of Bezimenne, in the Donetsk region, in May.

item.title: Head of Documenta Resigns Amid Antisemitism Scandal
item.description: A crisis at one of the world’s most important art events, in Germany, has deepened with the resignation of its director general.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors at the Museum Fridericianum in June during the Documenta contemporary art exhibition in Kassel, Germany.

item.title: As Biden Reaches Out to Mideast Dictators, His Eyes Are on China and Russia
item.description: Looking to make Moscow pay for its Ukraine war, and box China out of Mideast tech deals, the U.S. president tries to fall back on old Gulf alliances.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Peter Baker
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Eugenio Scalfari, Leading Italian Journalist, Dies at 98
item.description: As a founder of La Repubblica, one of the country’s major newspapers, and later as a columnist, he left a mark on civic life.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.media:description: Eugenio Scalfari in 1992. He was a founder of the newspaper La Repubblica, a major force in Italian journalism.

item.title: Moscow Signals a Shift to a More Aggressive Phase of Ukraine War
item.description: After a brief pause, the Russian military is ramping up activity “in all operational sectors” in the Donbas region, the defense minister said.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A store hit by shelling in Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Saturday. Ukrainian military officials said Ukrainian troops repelled an overnight assault by Russia to capture the main road link between the cities of Lysychansk and Bakhmut.

item.title: How Biden’s Mideast Efforts on Oil Resemble Jimmy Carter’s
item.description: Jimmy Carter flew to Tehran in 1977 to meet the shah of Iran.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:description: President Jimmy Carter toasted Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi of Iran during a New Year's Eve dinner at Niavaran Palace in Tehran in 1977.

item.title: Biden Says He Confronted Saudi Prince Over Jamal Khashoggi. How True Is That?
item.description: Mr. Biden is by nature a storyteller with a history of relating dramatic tales of conversations with foreign leaders that others in the room do not recall the same way.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia during a summit in Jeddah on Saturday, one day after their encounter.

item.title: Wildfires, and a Heat Wave, Sweep Across Europe
item.description: Fires in the south of France have burned more than 22,000 acres and prompted widespread evacuations. Britain was bracing for record high temperatures early next week.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: A restaurant destroyed by flames on Friday near La Teste-de-Buch, in southwestern France.

item.title: Salad Days
item.description: When it comes to making the perfect summer salad, sometimes less is more.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: One Result of Biden’s Meeting With Saudi Prince: A Setback in the Khashoggi Case
item.description: President Biden’s dropping of his resistance to speak with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman seems to signal the end of official U.S. efforts to seek justice for the slain journalist.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Saudi officials eventually acknowledged Jamal Khashoggi’s murder, but insisted that it had been carried out by rogue agents with no orders from Riyadh.

item.title: Toronto’s Pearson Airport Struggles With Flight Delays
item.description: Airports around the world are struggling to keep pace with the summer travel boom.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Travelers crowded the security queue in the departures lounge at Toronto Pearson International Airport in May.

item.title: Passengers Sigh as Heathrow Caps Numbers to Head Off ‘Airmageddon’
item.description: After two years of pandemic-enforced staycations, demand for travel has come roaring back in Europe, and airports are finding it impossible to keep up.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Travelers on Wednesday at London’s Heathrow Airport. The airport has capped the number of departing passengers until September.

item.title: Did Nature Heal During the Pandemic ‘Anthropause’?
item.description: Covid precautions created a global slowdown in human activity — and an opportunity to learn more about the complex ways we affect other species.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A lone duck savoring its hegemony over the Place de la Concorde in Paris, during coronavirus pandemic lockdowns in the spring of 2020.

item.title: Getting a Passport Will Be Another Pain for Summer Travels
item.description: If you’re urgently in need of a new or updated passport, brace yourself: Options have narrowed — and it’s likely going to cost you.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin

item.title: Dead but Not Buried, Angola’s Ex-President’s Body Sparks a Continental Fight
item.description: José Eduardo dos Santos ruled Angola for 38 years. But he died in Spain. A dispute over where to lay him to rest has divided his family and could decide the fate of his political party.
item.dc:creator: Gilberto Neto, José Bautista and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: With his body still in Spain, a portrait was the official focus of mourning in Luanda this week for José Eduardo dos Santos, Angola’s president from 1979 to 2017.

item.title: How We Counted Egypt’s Invisible Detainees
item.description: There was no public accounting of the prisoners in the black hole of Egypt’s indefinite pretrial detention. Until now.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Allison McCann and Josh Holder
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Biden’s Visit to Saudi Arabia Draws Criticism and Modest Accords
item.description: In the most politically problematic trip of his presidency, Mr. Biden’s critics accused him of helping rehabilitate the reputation of a tarnished prince in exchange for numerous, but limited gains.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and David E. Sanger
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Biden’s welcome in Saudi Arabia was polite but perfunctory compared with the enthusiastic greeting President Donald J. Trump received in 2017.

item.title: Demand for Monkeypox Vaccine Exceeds Supply, C.D.C. Says
item.description: The United States has ordered nearly seven million doses in total, but most of them will not arrive for months.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining up to receive monkeypox vaccinations at a sexual health clinic in New York City.

item.title: 4-Year-Old Girl Dies in Russian Strike in Vinnytsia
item.description: A toddler with Down syndrome was happily pushing a stroller through a Ukraine park before a Russian missile landed. “I want to shout out to the whole world,” an anguished survivor of the attack cried.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The stroller that Liza Dmytriyeva was pushing before she was killed in the Russian missile attack on Vinnytsia, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Mexican Activists Answer Calls for Abortion Pills From the U.S.
item.description: As more U.S. states move to criminalize abortion, activists in Mexico have been inundated with calls from women seeking abortion medication. Our cameras went inside their distribution effort.
item.dc:creator: Brent McDonald, Paula Mónaco Felipe, Caroline Kim, Souleyman Messalti and Miguel Tovar
item.media:credit: Miguel Tovar for The New York Times
item.media:description:
In July, Verónica Cruz Sánchez, the founder and leader of Las Libres in Guanajuato, Mexico responds to a request for abortion pills from the U.S.
NYTCREDIT: Miguel Tovar for The New York Times

item.title: Mexico Captures Notorious Drug Kingpin Rafael Caro Quintero
item.description: Rafael Caro Quintero, an accused drug cartel leader, was convicted of killing Enrique Camarena, a Drug Enforcement Administration agent, and was wanted by the F.BI.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: Rafael Caro Quintero, center, was convicted of orchestrating the 1985 torture and killing of Enrique Camarena, a Drug Enforcement Administration agent who was working undercover in Mexico.

item.title: Biden Said He Rebuked the Saudi Crown Prince Over Khashoggi’s Murder
item.description: Mr. Khashoggi, a Saudi contributor to The Washington Post who was critical of the prince’s rule, was killed in Istanbul in 2018.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Biden’s welcome in Saudi Arabia was polite but perfunctory compared with the enthusiastic greeting President Donald J. Trump received in 2017.

item.title: Biden Offers Differing Messages for Israelis and Palestinians
item.description: To Israelis, President Biden’s visit was mostly a source of celebration of growing ties with Arab countries. For the Palestinians, Mr. Biden brought funding and sympathy — but no long-term plans.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: President Biden met with the president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, in the West Bank on Friday, but said that “the ground is not ripe at this moment to restart negotiations” to end the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

item.title: Four Ways the United States Can Still Fight Climate Change
item.description: With the president’s most potent tools to fight climate change stripped by Congress and the courts, the administration will now have to rely on smaller, less powerful actions.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Manchin’s decision and the Supreme Court decision smashed the building that the Biden administration was constructing to meet this very ambitious climate target,” one legal expert said.
